title: Why is there a "b" in doubt? - Gina Cooke

options.text: It comes from the French word "douter".

options.label: D
options.text: It comes from the Greek word "apistia".

multiple-choice.question: Why was the "b" reinserted into the spelling of the word "doubt"?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it was a common spelling pattern in English at the time.

options.label: B
options.text: Because scribes who wrote English but also knew Latin, understood that the root of "doubt" had a "b" in it.

options.text: Because it was a mistake that was carried over from Latin to English.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it was a deliberate attempt to make the word more difficult to spell.

options.label: D

options.label: D

title: Situational irony: The opposite of what you think - Christopher Warner

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why people often misinterpret the term "irony"?

options.label: C

options.text: Being able to identify what is not expected in a situation.

options.text: A cartoonist is a creator, and their cartoon is a separate entity.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: A cartoonist is a participant, and their cartoon is a dance of words, ideas, and images.

options.label: D
options.text: A cartoonist is a creator, and their cartoon is a reflection of their imagination.

options.label: C

title: How did English evolve? - Kate Gardoqui

multiple-choice.question: What was the benefit for the Celts when the Romans ruled Britain?

options.label: A
options.text: The Celts were able to conquer the Romans.

options.label: B
options.text: The Celts were able to form their own kingdoms.

options.label: C
options.text: The Romans protected the Celts from the barbarian Saxon tribes of Northern Europe.

options.label: D
options.text: The Celts were able to take over the Roman Empire.

multiple-choice.question: What happened to the Roman Empire, and what was the result for the Celts?

options.label: A
options.text: The Roman Empire grew stronger, and the Celts were able to expand their territories.

options.label: B
options.text: The Roman Empire began to crumble, and the Romans withdrew from Britain.

options.label: C
options.text: The Roman Empire was taken over by the Celts.

options.label: D
options.text: The Roman Empire was destroyed by the barbarian Saxon tribes.

multiple-choice.question: What happened to the Germanic tribes, the Angles, Saxons, Jutes, and Frisians after the Romans withdrew from Britain?

options.label: A
options.text: They formed alliances with the Celts.

options.label: B
options.text: They sailed across the water and formed kingdoms in the British Isles.

options.label: C
options.text: They stayed in Northern Europe and did not interact with the Celts.

options.label: D
options.text: They were defeated by the Romans.

multiple-choice.question: What language became the common language in Britain after the Germanic tribes settled there?
What happened to the language of the Saxons when they interacted with the Danish neighbors?

options.label: A
options.text: It became more complex and difficult to understand.

options.label: B
options.text: It became simpler and easier to understand.

options.label: C
options.text: It mixed with Old Norse and many Old Norse words are still a part of our language.

options.label: D
options.text: It was replaced by Old Norse.

multiple-choice.question: What happened to the British Isles in 1066?

options.label: A
options.text: The Normans were defeated by the Saxons.

options.label: B
options.text: The Saxons were defeated by the Normans.

options.label: C
options.text: The Normans placed a Norman king on the English throne.

options.label: D
options.text: The Normans withdrew from the British Isles.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the Norman conquest on the language of the British royalty?

options.label: A
options.text: French became the language of the British peasants.

options.label: B
options.text: French became the language of the British royalty.

options.label: C
options.text: English became the language of the British royalty.

options.label: D
options.text: Latin became the language of the British royalty.

multiple-choice.question: What happened to the language of the Saxons as a result of the Norman conquest?

options.label: A
options.text: It became more complex and difficult to understand.

options.label: B
options.text: It became simpler and easier to understand.

options.label: C
options.text: It adapted and grew as thousands of words flowed in, many having to do with government, law, and aristocracy.

multiple-choice.question: Why did Anglo Saxon words seem plain compared to French words?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they were more complex and difficult to understand.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they were more simple and easy to understand.

options.label: C
options.text: Because Anglo Saxon words were associated with the common people, while French words were associated with the nobility.

options.label: D
options.text: Because Saxon words were more formal and French words were more informal.

multiple-choice.question: What does the history of the English language reveal about the feelings and associations that people have with different words?

options.label: A
options.text: It reveals that people's feelings and associations are random and have no basis in history.

options.label: B
options.text: It reveals that people's feelings and associations are determined by their personal experiences.

options.label: C
options.text: It reveals that people's feelings and associations are influenced by the history of the words they speak and hear.

options.label: D
options.text: It reveals that people's feelings and associations are determined by their social status.

title: DNA: The book of you - Joe Hanson

multiple-choice.question: What is the starting point of every human being?

options.text: Two cells, one from each parent, found each other and became one.

options.label: B
options.text: A single cell that reproduces itself.

options.label: C
options.text: 10 trillion cells that aren't just sitting there in a big pile.

options.label: D
options.text: A tiny book of instructions found in each and every cell.

multiple-choice.question: How many cells are there in one person's body?
What is it that says a nose is a nose, and toes is toes?

options.label: A
options.text: Everything you are or ever will be made of starts as a tiny book of instructions found in each and every cell.

options.label: B
options.text: The 10 trillion cells in one person's body.

options.label: C
options.text: The tiny variations in each person's genome.

options.label: D
options.text: The instructions in the book of you, your genome.

multiple-choice.question: What is the first thing we see when we take a journey inside a single cell to find out what makes up the book of you, your genome?

options.label: A
options.text: The whole genome, all your DNA, is contained inside its own tiny compartment, called the nucleus.

options.label: B
options.text: The 10 trillion cells in one person's body.

options.label: C
options.text: The tiny variations in each person's genome.

options.label: D
options.text: The instructions in the book of you, your genome.

multiple-choice.question: How long would it take to type all the copy of the book of you, your genome?
How many chapters does the book of you have?
What determines if you're male or female?

options.label: A
options.text: Two of those chapters, called "X" and "Y"

options.label: C
options.text: The tiny variations in each person's genome.

options.label: D
options.text: The instructions in the book of you, your genome.

multiple-choice.question: How many individual instructions, called genes, are there in the book of you?
What are the parts we throw out in the book of you, your genome?

options.label: A
options.text: The instructions we keep, we call exons.

options.label: B
options.text: The parts we throw out, we call introns.

options.label: C
options.text: The 10 trillion cells in one person's body.

options.label: D
options.text: The tiny variations in each person's genome.

title: The genius of Mendeleev’s periodic table

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the periodic table created by Dmitri Mendeleev?

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: It contains a blank spot that Mendeleev predicted would be filled by a new element.

options.label: D
options.text: It's not relevant to the question.
